EDIT: "Mid-term elections to Congress on June 6 could change the balance of power, causing the governing Morena party and allies to lose their two-thirds majority in the lower house, which would make it more difficult to approve constitutional changes. However, it might still be possible to approve changes in Congress (these also require ratification by a majority of state legislatures). An alternative referendum route exists for approving constitutional reforms, but reforms affecting government revenue and spending are not be eligible. A recall referendum on President Lopez Obrador's continuation in office may be held in 1H22." https://www.fitchratings.com/research/sovereigns/fitch-affirms-mexico-at-bbb-outlook-stable-17-05-2021

The first referendum would be in 2022 per https://www.infobae.com/america/mexico/2019/11/06/el-senado-aprobo-la-revocacion-de-mandato-el-primer-referendum-seria-en-2022/ Unless the opposition advances the date. At a 53% approval rating, it's risky for the opposition to elevate him, and there isn't much time left to do that.

Increasing the likelihood of there not being a referendum following a lack of news about this. AMLO likes to publicize proposed referendums in order to drum up support and I have not seen him do so yet. He is also less likely to want a referendum following his poor handling of COVID-19.

GZeroMedia: Mexico's July mid-term legislative election will be a referendum — perhaps literally — on left-populist president Andrés Manuel López Obrador, who has remained popular despite mishandling the coronavirus pandemic. López Obrador has proposed including a recall vote on his own presidency on the same ballot.
Seeing crowd forecast & realizing I feel I overvalued the likelihood of a referendum vote like this.

Populist party leader's big claim has been to rid Mexican presidency of corruption. López Obrador is pretty popular- 64%- highest approval ratings yet in Nov 2020 due to widespread approval of his social programs & how he has handled COVID. Down to 62% in Dec 2020. One blog I have found is that he (also?) wants to have a public vote on whether to prosecute and convict previous President's for corruption. His party does have majority in the house so with that and his general approval, he could probably make this referendum on his Presidency happen though it has enough procedural/legal question or challenge to occur as this is not a normal election.

From my understanding the Mexico senate have allowed the recall referendum (it needed a 2/3 majority to amend the constitution- https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-09/lopez-obrador-s-path-to-changing-the-constitution-in-mexico), on the condition it was held after the June 21 midterm elections, in this case in 2022. It is feasible that the senate could change its mind and bring it forward to June 21 but that would require both the opposition and AMLO to believe they had something to gain from that, which seems unlikely (6%) as both sides have a blocking vote. If for some reason, the vote did go ahead early it would be pretty much a 50/50 vote as both sides would believe they would win, so will allocate 3% each.

In 2018, president Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s (AMLO) primary goal in calling for a 2021 recall referendum was to increase turnout and thus increase his odds of keeping majorities in Mexico’s Congress. As a populist with massive approval ratings, AMLO assumed that increased turnout could only strengthen his chances.
Mexico seems chaotic and AMLO has not had a great favorability rating. Why would he put himself on the line?
I don’t understand what would be gained. He will be viewed as a failure by history.

I believe the first to look at here is the President’s rationale for calling a referendum during the mid-term elections. Mexico would appear to be in a mess. Economically Mexico was in recession prior to the Covid pandemic that has further deepened the economy by 18.9% by the second quarter. The handling of the pandemic has resulted in 133,000 deaths – one of the world’s highest. In 2019 there were 34,500 reported homicides with 2020 even worse. Mexico is ranked 130 out of 198 in the Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI) President López Obrador has possibly seen a possible distraction from his fall in popularity and the countries woes by using the expose by the discredited ex-head of Pemex (National Oil Company) Emilio Lozoya of implicating previous Presidents, including aides and lawmakers, Felipe Calderón – president from 2006 until 2012 – and Carlos Salinas – from 1988 to 1994 of corruption, cronyism and increasing the concentration of wealth for themselves and families. Lopez has stated that five former presidents, Carlos Salinas, Ernesto Zedillo, Vicente Fox, Felipe Calderon and Enrique Pena Nieto should stand trial for corruption, concentration of wealth etc. and that the Mexican people should decide. Mexico’s Supreme court have approved Lopez’s plan to hold a referendum on whether the previous presidents should be held to account, without naming them. Referendums are considered to be dangerous by the political class as it places decision(s) in the hands of the populace, but Lopez might see this as a distraction to bolster his anti-corruption credentials. 50% for the distraction, 50% as he is unpopular

There’s a lot more downside risk to a referendum than upside opportunity. Lose it and you’re crippled for the second half of your term. Win it...and what? Bragging rights? He may be hoping he can use his popularity to help his party in the mid terms. But I think he knows the risk outweighs the gain and will not follow through.
Obrador is only talking, he won't risk a referendum

A quick search in google for polls [1] and economic indicators [2] show a (having just a very quick look) relatively comfortable position, with approval at 60%, stock market strong, reduced inflation and unemployment going down, not like a year ago but blame COVID. Only major issue would be COVID [3] and the very high number of deaths. So, reasons for this could be to condition the results of the midterm elections to his personal charisma (his party, Morena, doesn't seem to be doing too bad, and no other party seems to be closing the gap [1]) or first step to change his six year term [4]. Not reasonable but populists sometimes don't think straight and don't have a "memento mori" slave.
If people learned nothing else from brexit, it should be not to hold an unnecessary referendum.
